DIV1.P: THE GUARDIAN. A COMEDY OF TWO ACTS.
As it is perform'd at the THEATRE-ROYAL in Drury-Lane.

LONDON: Printed for J. NEWBERY, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard; and Sold by R. BAILYE, at Litchfield; J. LEAKE and W. FREDERICK, at Bath; B. COLLINS, at Salisbury; and S. STABLER at York.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: Mr. HEARTLY, the Guardian, Mr. GARRICK.
Mr. CLACKIT, his Nephew, Mr. OBRIEN.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: Miss HARRIET, an Heiress, Miss PRITCHARD.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: THE Pupille of Monsieur Fagan is mentioned by Voltaire, and other French Writers, as the most complete Petite-Piece upon their Stage.—It now appears in an English Dress, with such Alterations from the Original as the Difference of Language and Manners required.—It has more than answer'd the Expectations of the Author, who takes this Opportunity to return Thanks to the Publick for their kind Indulgence, and to the Performers for their great Care.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I.
A Hall in Mr. HEARTLY'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir CHARLES CLACKIT, his NEPHEW, and SERVANT.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: PLEASE to walk this Way, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Where is your Master, Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: In his Dressing-Room, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Let him know then—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Prithee be quiet, Jack; when I am in Company let me direct. 'Tis proper and decent.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: I am dumb, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Tell Mr. Heartly, his Friend and Neighbour, Sir Charles Clackit, would say three words to him.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: I shall, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Now Nephew, consider once again, before I open the Matter to my Neighbour Heartly, what I am going to undertake for you.—Why don't you speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Is it proper and decent, Uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Pshaw! don't be a Fool—but answer me—don't you flatter yourself.—What Assurance have you that this young Lady, my Friend's Ward, has a liking to you? The young Fellows of this Age are all Coxcombs, and I am afraid, you are no Exception to the general Rule.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P:
Thank you Uncle—But may I this Instant be struck old and peevish, if I would put you upon
a false Scent to expose you for all the fine Wo∣men in Christendom.—I assure you again and again, and you may take my Word, Uncle, that Miss Harriet has no kind of Aversion to your Ne∣phew and most humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, ay,—Vanity!—Vanity!—but I never take a young Fellow's Word about Women; they'll lye as fast, and with as little Conscience, as the Brussels Gazette.—Produce your Proofs.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Can't your Eyes see 'em, Uncle, without urging me to the Indelicacy of repeating 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Why I see nothing but a Fool's Head and a Fool's Coat, supported by a pair of most unpro∣mising Legs. Have you no better Proofs?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Yes, I have, my good Infidel Uncle, half a hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Out with them then.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: First then—Whenever I see her, she never looks at me.—That's a Sign of Love.—Whenever I speak to her, she never answers me.—Another Sign of Love.—And whenever I speak to any Body else, she seems to be perfectly easy.—That's a certain Sign of Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: The Devil it is!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: When I am with her, she's always grave; and the Moment I get up to leave her, then the poor Thing begins—“Why will you leave me, Mr. Clackit; can't you sacrifice a few Moments to my Bashfulness?—Stay, you agreeable Run∣away, stay, I shall soon overcome the Fears your Presence gives me.”—I cou'd say more,— But a Man of Honour, Uncle—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: What, and has she said all these Things to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: O yes, and ten times more—with her Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: With her Eyes!—Eyes are very equivocal, Jack.—However, if the young Lady has any Liking to you, Mr. Heartly is too much a Man of the World, and too much my Friend, to oppose the Match; so do you walk into the Garden, and I will open the Matter to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT
SP.P: Is there any Objection to my staying, Uncle? The Business will be soon ended.—You will pro∣pose the Match, he will give his Consent, I shall give mine, Miss is sent for, and l'affair est fait.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: And so you think that a young beautiful Heiress, with Forty Thousand Pounds, is to be had with a Scrap of French, and a Snap of your Finger.—Prithee get away, and don't provoke me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Nay, but, my dear Uncle—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Nay, but my impertinent Nephew, either retire, or I'll throw up the Game.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Well, well, I am gone, Uncle.—When you come to the Point, I shall be ready to make my Appearance.—Bon Voyage!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: The Devil's in these young Fellows, I think—We send 'em abroad to cure their Sheepishness, and they get above Proof the other way.—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: And to you, Sir Charles, I am glad to see you so strong and healthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I can return you the Compliment, my Friend,—Without Flattery you don't look more than Thirty-five; and between ourselves, you are on the wrong Side of Forty—But Mum for that.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Ease and Tranquility keep me as you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Why don't you marry Neighbour? A good Wife would do well for you.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: For me? you are pleased to be merry Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: No faith, I am serious, and had I a Daughter to recommend to you, you should say me nay more than once, I assure you, Neighbour Heartly, be∣fore I would quit you.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I am much obliged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: But indeed, you are a little too much of the Philosopher, to think of being troubled with Wo∣men and their Concerns.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P:
I beg your Pardon Sir Charles—Tho' there are many, who call themselves Philosophers, that live single, and perhaps are in the right of it, yet I cannot think that Marriage is at all inconsistent
with true Philosophy.—A wise Man will resolve to live like the rest of the World, with this only Dif∣ference, that he is neither a Slave to Passions nor Events.—It is not because I have a little Philoso∣phy, but because I am on the wrong Side of forty Sir Charles, that I desire to be excused (smiling).

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: As you please, Sir,—and now to my Business—You have no Objection I suppose to tie up your Ward, Miss Harriet, though you have slipped the Collar yourself—Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Quite the contrary, Sir; I have taken her some time from the Boarding School, and brought her home, in order to dispose of her worthily, with her own Inclination.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Her Father, I have heard you say, recommended that particular Care to you, when she had reached a certain Age.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: He did so—and I am the more desirous to obey him scrupulously in this Circumstance, as she will be a most valuable Acquisition to the Person who shall gain her—for, not to mention her Fortune, which is the least Consideration, her Sentiments are worthy her Birth; she is gentle, modest, and obliging.—In a Word, my Friend, I never saw Youth more amiable or discreet,—but perhaps I am a little partial to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: No, no, she is a delicious Creature, every body says so.—But I believe, Neighbour, something has happened that you little think off.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: What, pray Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: My Nephew, Mr. Heartly—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Here I am at your Service, Sir,—My Uncle is a little unhappy in his Manner; but I'll clear the Matter in a Moment—Miss Harriet, Sir,—Your Ward.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Get away, you Puppy!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Miss Harriet, Sir, your Ward,—a most accomp∣lish'd young Lady, to be sure—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Thou art a most accomplish'd Coxcomb, to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Pray, Sir Charles, let the young Gentleman speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: You'll excuse me, Mr. Heartly—My Uncle does not set up for an Orator,—a little confused, or so, Sir,—You see me what I am,—But I ought to ask Pardon for the young Lady and myself.—We are young, Sir,—I must confess we were wrong to con∣ceal it from you,—but my Uncle I see is pleased to be angry, and therefore, I shall say no more at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: If you don't leave the Room this Moment, and stay in the Garden, till I call you—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: I am sorry I have displeased you—I did not think it was mal-a-propos; but you must have your way Uncle—You command—I submit—Mr. Heartly, your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Puppy! (aside) My Nephew's a little unthink∣ing, Mr. Heartly, as you see, and therefore I have been a little cautious how I have proceeded in this Affair: But indeed, he has perswaded me in a Manner, that your Ward and he are not ill to∣gether.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P:
Indeed! This is the first Notice I have had of it, and I cannot conceive why Miss Harriet should conceal it from me; for I have often assured her,
that I would never oppose her Inclination, though I might endeavour to direct it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: 'Tis human Nature, Neighbour,—We are so ashamed of our first Passion, that we would willing∣ly hide it from ourselves—But will you mention my Nephew to her.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I must beg your Pardon, Sir Charles,—The Name of the Gentleman whom she chuses, must first come from herself,—My Advice or Importu∣nity shall never influence her: If Guardians would be less rigorous, young People would be more reasonable; and I am so unfashionable to think, that Happiness in Marriage can't be bought too dear.—I am still on the wrong Side of Forty, Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: No, no,—You are right Neighbour,—But here she is,—Don't alarm her young Heart too much, I beg of you,—Upon my Word, she is a sweet Morsel.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: He is with Company—I'll speak to him another Time.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Young, handsome, and afraid of being seen.—You are very particular, Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Miss Harriet you must not go.—(Harriet returns) Sir Charles, give me leave to introduce you to this young Lady.—(Introduces her) You know, I sup∣pose, the Reason of this Gentleman's Visit to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Sir! (confused.)

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: You may trust me, my Dear (smiling)—Don't be disturb'd I shall not reproach you with any thing, but keeping your Wishes a Secret from me so long.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: —Upon my Word, Sir,—Lucy!

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Well, and Lucy! I'll lay my Life 'tis a Treaty of Marriage.—Is that such a dreadful Thing? Oh, for shame, Madam! Young Ladies of Fashion are not frightened at such Things now a days.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY to Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: We have gone too far, Sir Charles,—We must excuse her Delicacy, and give her Time to re∣cover,—I had better talk with her alone; we will leave her now;—Be perswaded that no En∣deavours shall be wanting on my Part, to bring this Affair to a happy and a speedy Conclusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P:
I shall be obliged to you, Mr. Heartly.—Young Lady your Servant.—What Grace and Modesty!
She is a most engaging Creature, and I shall be proud to make her one of my Family.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: You do us Honour, Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Indeed, Miss Harriet, you are very particular; you was tired of the Boarding School, and yet seem to have no Inclination to be married.—What can be the Meaning of all this?—That smirking old Gentle∣man is Uncle to Mr. Clackit; and, my Life for it, he has made some Proposals to your Guardian.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Prithee don't plague me about Mr. Clackit.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: But why not, Miss? Tho' he is a little fantasti∣cal, loves to hear himself talk, and is somewhat self-sufficient; you must consider he is young, has been abroad, and keeps good Company:—The trade will soon be at an end, if young Ladies and Gentlemen grow over nice and exceptious.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: But if I can find one without these Faults, I may surely please myself.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Without these Faults! and is he young, Miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P:
He is sensible, modest, polite, affable, and ge∣nerous; and charms from the natural Impulses of his
own Heart, as much as others disgust by their sense∣less Airs, and insolent Affectation.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Upon my word!—But why have you kept this Secret so long?—Your Guardian is kind to you be∣yond Conception.—What Difficulties can you have to overcome?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Why the Difficulty of declaring my Sentiments.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Leave that to me, Miss.—But your Spark, with all his Accomplishments, must have very little Pene∣tration not to have discovered his good Fortune in your Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I take care that my Eyes don't tell too much; and he has too much Delicacy to interpret Looks to his Advantage. Besides, he would certainly disapprove my Passion; and if I should ever make the Decla∣ration, and meet with a Denial, I should abso∣lutely die with Shame.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: I'll ensure your Life for a Silver Thimble.—But what can possibly hinder your coming together?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: His Excess of Merit.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P:
His Excess of a Fiddlestick;—But come, I'll put you in the way;—You shall trust me with the Secret;—I ll entrust it again to half a dozen Friends, they
shall entrust it to half a dozen more, by which Means it will travel half the Town over in a Week's time; the Gentleman will certainly hear of it, and then if he is not at your Feet in the fetching of a Sigh, I'll give up all my Perquisites at your Wedding.—What is his Name, Miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I cannot tell you his Name,—Indeed I cannot; I am afraid of being thought too singular.—But why should I be ashamed of my Passion? Is the Impres∣sion which a virtuous Character makes upon our Hearts such a Weakness that it may not be excused?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: By my Faith, Miss, I can't understand you: You are afraid of being thought singular, and you really are so:—I would sooner renounce all the Passions in the Universe than have one in my Bosom beating and fluttering itself to pieces—Come, come, Miss, open the Window and let the poor Devil out.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Leave us, Lucy.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: There's something going forward,—'tis very hard I can't be of the Party.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: She certainly thinks, from the Character of the young Man, that I shall disapprove of her Choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: What can I possibly say to him? I am as much ashamed to make the Declaration, as he would be to understand it.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Don't imagine, my Dear, that I would know more of your Thoughts than you desire I should; but the tender Care which I have ever shewn, and the sincere Friendship which I shall always have for you, give me a sort of Right to enquire into every thing that concerns you.—Some Friends have spoken to me in particular,—But that is not all,—I have lately found you thoughtful, absent, and disturbed;—Be plain with me,—Has not some body been happy enough to please you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I cannot deny it, Sir;—Yes,—Somebody indeed has pleased me;—But I must intreat you not to give Credit to any idle Stories, or enquire farther into the Particulars of my Inclination; for I cannot possibly have Resolution enough to say more to you.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: But have you made a Choice, my Dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I have, in my own Mind, Sir; and 'tis impossible to make a better;—Reason, Honour, every thing must approve it.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: And how long have you conceived this Passion?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Ever since I left the Country—to live with you.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I see your Confusion, my Dear, and will relieve you from it immediately,—I am informed of the whole—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Don't be uneasy, for I can with Pleasure assure you, that your Passion is return'd with equal Ten∣derness.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: If you are not deceiv'd—I cannot be more happy.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I think I am not deceiv'd;—But after the De∣claration you have made, and the Assurances which I have given you, why will you conceal it any longer? Have I not deserv'd a little more Confidence from you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: You have indeed deserv'd it, and shou'd cer∣tainly have it, were I not well assur'd that you wou'd oppose my Inclinations.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I oppose 'em! Am I then so unkind to you, my Dear?—Can you in the least doubt of my Af∣fection for you?—I promise you that I have no Will but your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Since you desire it then, I will endeavour to explain myself.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY,
SP.P: I am all Attention;—Speak, my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: And if I do, I feel I shall never be able to speak to you again.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: How can that be, when I shall agree with you in every thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Indeed you won't:—Pray let me retire to my own Chamber,—I am not well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I see your Delicacy is hurt, my Dear: But let me intreat you once more to confide in me.— Tell me his Name, and the next Moment I will go to him, and assure him, that my Consent shall confirm both your Happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P:
You will easily find him,—And when you have, pray tell him how improper it is for a young Wo∣man to speak first,—Perswade him to spare my Blushes, and to release me from so terrible a Situ∣ation,—I shall leave him with you,—And hope
that this Declaration will make it impossible for you to mistake me any longer.

DIV3.STAGE: [HARRIET is going, but upon seeing Y. CLACKIT, remains upon the Stage.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Are we not alone? What can this mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Apropos Faith! Here they are together.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I did not see him;—But now the Riddle's ex∣plain'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: What can he want now?—This is the most spiteful Interruption.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: By your Leave, Mr. Heartly—

DIV3.P: —Have I caught you at last my divine Harriet.—Well, Mr. Heartly, Sans Façon—But what's the Matter, ho!—Things look a little gloomy here;—One mutters to himself, and gives me no Answer, and the other turns the Head, and winks at me.—How the Devil am I to interpret all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I wink at you, Sir! Did I, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Yes, you my Angel;—But Mum,—Mr. Heartly, for Heaven's Sake, what is all this? Speak, I conjure you, is it Life or Death with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: What a dreadful Situation I am in!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Hope for the best,—I'll bring Matters about I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: You have both of you great Reason to be satis∣fied,—Nothing shall oppose your Happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Bravo, Mr. Heartly!

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Miss Harriet's Will is a Law to me; and for you, Sir,—the Friendship which I have ever pro∣fess'd for your Uncle is too sincere not to exert some of it upon this Occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I shall die with Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: I am alive again,—Dear Mr. Heartly, thou art a most adorable Creature! What a Happiness it is to have to do with a Man of Sense, who has no foolish Prejudices, and can see when a young Fellow has something tolerable about him!—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P:
Sir, not to flatter you, I must declare, that it is from a Knowledge of your Friends and Family, that I have Hopes of seeing you and this young
Lady happy. I will go directly to your Uncle, and assure him that every thing goes on to our Wishes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Mr. Heartly,—Pray, Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Poor Miss Harriet, I see your Distress, and am sorry for it; but it must be got over, and the sooner the better.—Mr. Clackit, my Dear, will be glad of an Opportunity to entertain you, for the little Time that I shall be absent!—Poor Miss Har∣riet!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Allez, allez, Monsieur!—I'll answer for that,—Well Ma'am I think every thing succeeds to our Wishes;—Be sincere, my Adorable,—Don't you think yourself a very happy young Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I shall be most particularly obliged to you, Sir, if you would inform me what is the meaning of all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Inform you, Miss?—The Matter, I believe, is pretty clear,—Our Friends have Understanding, we have Affections,—And a Marriage follows of Course.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Marriage, Sir. Pray what Relation or parti∣cular Connexion is there between you and me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: I may be deceiv'd Faith;—But upon my Ho∣nour, I always supposed that there was a little Smatt'ring of Inclination between us.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: And have you spoke to my Guardian upon this Supposition, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: And are you angry at it? I believe not.— (Smiling.) Come, come, I believe not,—'Tis de∣licate in you to be upon the Reserve.—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, this Behaviour of yours is most ex∣traordinary.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Come, come, my Dear, don't carry this Jest too far, è troppo, è troppo mia Carissima.—What the Devil, when every Thing is agreed upon, and Uncles and Guardians, and such Folks have given their Consent, why continue the Hypocrisy?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: They may have consented for you; but I am Mistress of my Affections, and will never dispose of 'em by Proxy.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Upon my Soul this is very droll;—What! has not your Guardian been here this Moment, and expressed all imaginable Pleasure at our intended Union.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: He is in an Error, Sir,—And had I not been too much astonished at your Behaviour, I had un∣deceiv'd him long before now.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: But, pray, Miss, to return to Business—What can be your Intention in raising all this Confusion in the Family, and opposing your own Inclina∣tions?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Opposing my own Inclinations, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Ay, opposing your own Inclinations, Madam,—Do you know, Child, if you carry on this Farce any longer, I shall begin to be a little angry?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I would wish it, Sir,—for be assur'd, that I never in my Life had the least Thought about you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Words, Words, Words—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: 'Tis most sincerely and literally true.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Come, come, I know what I know—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Don't make yourself ridiculous, Mr. Clackit.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Don't you make yourself miserable, Miss Harriet.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I am only so, when you persist to torment me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT, (Smiling.)
SP.P: And you really believe, that you don't love me?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Positively not.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT, (Conceitedly.)
SP.P: And you are very sure now, that you hate me?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Oh! Most cordially.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Poor young Lady! I do pity you from my Soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Then why won't you leave me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.L: But let Concealment like a Worm i'th' bud,
SP.P:
Take warning Miss, when you once begin to pine in Thought, its all over with you, and be assured, since you are obstinately bent to give yourself Airs, that, if you once suffer me to leave this House, in a Pet—Do you mind me?—Not all your signing, whining, Fits, Vapours and Hystericks, shall ever
move me to take the least Compassion on you— Coute qui Coute—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I am overjoy'd to hear it;—There they are, the pretty Doves! That is the Age, Neighbour Heartly, for Happiness and Pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I am willing, you see, to lose no Time, which may convince you, Sir Charles, how proud I am of this Alliance in our Families.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: The Thoughts of it rejoices me,—Gad, I will send for the Fiddles, and take a Dance myself, and a Fig for the Gout and Rheumatism.—But hold, hold,—The Lovers, methinks, are a little out of Humour with each other.—What is the Matter, Jack? Not pouting sure before your Time.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: A trifle, Sir,—The Lady will tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: You seem to be troubled Harriet.—What can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P:
You have been in an Error, Sir, about me;—I did not undeceive you, because I could not ima∣gine,
that the Consequences could have been so se∣rious and so sudden;—But I am now forced to tell you, that you have misunderstood me—That you have distressed me—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: How, my Dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: What do you say Miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Mademoiselle is pleased to be out of Humour, but I can't blame her, for upon my Honour, I think a little Coquetry becomes her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, ay, ay,—Oh, ho!—Is that all? These little Squalls seldom overset the Lover's Boat, but drive it the faster to Port—Ay, ay, ay—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Don't be uneasy, my Dear, that you have de∣clared your Passion,—Be consistent now, lest you should be thought capricious.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Talk to her a little, Mr. Heartly, she is a fine Lady, and has many Virtues, but she does not know the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Come, come, you must be Friends again, my Children.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I beg you will let me alone, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Miss Harriet, explain this Riddle to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I cannot, Sir,—I have discovered the Weakness of my Heart—I have discovered it to you, Sir;— But your unkind Interpretations and reproachful Looks, convince me, that I have already said but too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Well but hark'ye, Nephew,—This is going a little too far,—What have you done to her?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I never saw her so much moved before!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Upon my Soul, Gentlemen, I am as much surprized at it as you can be;—The little Bronil∣lerie between us, arose upon her persisting, that there was no Passion, no Penchant between us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, Jack,—There is a certain Kind of Impudence about you, that I don't ap∣prove of; and were I a young Girl, those Coxco∣mical Airs of your's would surfeit me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P:
But as the young Ladies are not quite so squea∣mish, as you Uncle, I fancy they will chuse me as I am. Ha! ha!—But what can the Lady object to? I have offered to marry her, is not that a Proof sufficient that I like her? A young Fellow
must have some Affection that will go such lengths to indulge it. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Why really, Friend Heartly, I don't see how a young Man can well do more, or a Lady desire more,—What say you, Neighbour?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Upon my Word, I am puzzled about it,— My Thoughts upon the Matter are so various, and so confused.—Every thing I see and hear is so contradictory—Is so—She certainly, cannot like any Body else?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: No, no, I'll answer for that—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Or she may be fearful then, that your Passion for her is not sincere, or like other young Men of the Times, you may grow careless upon Marriage and neglect her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Ha! Egad, you have hit it; nothing but a little natural delicate Sensibility—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: If so, perhaps, the Violence of her Reproaches may proceed from the Lukewarmness of your Pro∣fessions.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P:
Je vous demande pardon—I have sworn to her a hundred and a hundred Times, that she should be the happiest of her Sex;—But there is nothing surprizing in all this, it is the Misery of an over∣fond
Heart, to be always doubtful of its Happi∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: And if she marries thee I fear that she'll be kept in a State of Doubt as long as she lives.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Pray Gentlemen, what is the Matter among you? And which of you has affronted my Mistress? She is in a most prodigious taking yonder, and she vows to return into the Country again;—I can get nothing but Sighs from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Poor Thing!

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Poor Thing? The Devil take this Love, I say, There's more rout about it than 'tis worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: I beg your Pardon for that, Mrs. Ahigail.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I must enquire further in this; her Behaviour is too particular for me not to be disturbed at it.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: She desires, with the Leave of these Gentlemen, that when she has recover'd herself, she may talk with you alone, Sir. (To Heartly.)

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I shall with Pleasure attend her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y.CLACKIT.
SP.P: Divin Bacchus: La, la, la!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I wou'd give, old as I am, a Leg or an Arm to be belov'd by that sweet Creature as you are, Jack?

SP.SPEAKER: Y.CLACKIT.
SP.P: And throw your Gout and Rheumatism into the Bargain Uncle?—Ha, ha! Divin Bacchus. La, la, la, &c. (Sings.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: What the plague are you quavering at? Thou hast no more feeling for thy Happiness than my Stick here.

SP.SPEAKER: Y.CLACKIT.
SP.P: I beg your Pardon for that, my dear Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I wonder what the Devil is come to the young Fellows of this Age, Neighbour Heartly?—Why a fine Woman has no Effect upon 'em.—Is there no Method to make 'em less fond of themselves, and more mindful of the Ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I know but of one, Sir Charles.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Why to break all the Looking-Glasses in the Kingdom. (Pointing to Y. Clackit.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, ay, they are such Fops, so taken up with themselves!—Zounds, when I was young, and in Love—

SP.SPEAKER: Y.CLACKIT.
SP.P: You were a prodigious fine Sight, to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Look'ye, Mr. Clackit, if Miss Harriet's Affec∣tions declare for you, she must not be treated with Neglect or Disdain:—Nor cou'd I bear it, Sir.—Any Man must be proud of her Partiality to him, and he must be fashionably insensible indeed, who wou'd not make it his darling Care to defend, from every Inquietude, the most delicate and ten∣der of her Sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Most nobly and warmly said, Mr. Heartly.— Go to her, Nephew, directly,—Throw yourself at her Feet, and swear how much her Beauty and Virtue have captivated you, and don't let her go till you have set her dear little Heart at rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: I must desire to be excus'd,—Wou'd you have me say the same thing over and over again?— I can't do it possitively;—It is my turn to be piqu'd now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Damn your Conceit, Jack, I can bear it no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I am very sorry to find that any young Lady, so near and dear to me, shou'd bestow her Heart, where there is so little Prospect of its being va∣lued as it ought.—However, I shall not oppose my Authority to her Inclinations; and so—Who waits there? (Enter SERVANT.) Let the young Lady know that I shall attend her Commands in the Library. (Exit Servant.) Will you excuse me, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, ay,—We'll leave you to yourselves, and pray convince her, that I and my Nephew are most sincerely her very humble Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: O, yes, you may depend upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: A very slender Dependence truly. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: We'll be with you again to know what your Tete a Tete produces, and in the mean time, I am her's,—and your's,—Adieu. Come, Uncle,—Fal, lal, la, la!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I cou'd knock him down with Pleasure. (Aside.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, A Library.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY
SP.P: TELL Miss Harriet, that I am here.— If she is indisposed, I will wait upon her in her own Room.—

DIV3.P: However mysterious her Conduct appears to me, yet still it is to be de∣cyphered—This young Gentleman has certainly touch'd her—There are some Objections to him, and among so many young Men of Fashion that fall in her way, she certainly might have made a better Choice: She has an Understanding to be sensible of this; and, if I am not mistaken, it is a Struggle be∣tween her Reason and her Passion, that occasions all this Confusion.—But here she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I hope you are not angry, Sir, that I left you so abruptly, without making any Apology?—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P:
I am angry that you think any Apology necessary.—The Matter we were upon was of such a delicate
Nature, that I was more pleased with your Confusion, than I should have been with your Excuses.—You'll pardon me, my Dear.—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I have reflected, that the Person for whom I have conceiv'd a most tender Regard, may, from the wisest Motives, doubt of my Passion; and therefore I would endeavour to answer all his Objections, and convince him how deserving he is of my highest Es∣teem.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I have not yet apprehended what kind of Dispute could arise between you and Mr. Clackit:—I would advise you both to come to a Reconciliation as soon as possible.—The Law of Nature is an imperious one, and cannot, like those of our Country, be easily evaded; and though Reason may suggest some dis∣agreeable Reflections, yet when the Stroke is to be given, we must submit to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: He still continues in his Error, and I cannot un∣deceive him. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Shall I take the Liberty of telling you, my Dear. (Taking her Hand.)—You tremble, Harriet!— What is the matter with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Nothing, Sir.—Pray go on.—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P:
I guess whence proceeds all your Uneasiness.— You fear that the World will not be so readily con∣vinced of this young Gentleman's Merit as you are:
And, indeed, I could wish him more deserving of you; but your Regard for him gives him a Merit he otherwise would have wanted, and almost makes me blind to his Failings.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: And would you advise me, Sir, to make choice of this Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I would advise you, as I always have done, to consult your own Heart upon such an Occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: If that is your Advice, I will most religiously fol∣low it; and, for the last time, I am resolved to dis∣cover my real Sentiments; but as a Confession of this kind will not become me, I have been thinking of some innocent Stratagem to spare my Blushes, and in part to relieve me from the Shame of a Declaration.—Might I be permitted to write to him?—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I think you may, my Dear, without the least Of∣fence to your Delicacy: And indeed you ought to explain yourself; your late Misunderstanding makes it absolutely necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Will you be kind enough to assist me;—Will you write it for me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Oh, most willingly!—And as I am made a Party, it will remove all Objections.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I will dictate to you in the best Manner I am able. (Sighing.)

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: And here is Pen, Ink, and Paper, to obey your Commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Lord, how my Heart beats! I fear I cannot go thro' it.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Now, my Dear, I am ready.—Don't be disturb'd.—He is certainly a Man of Family, and tho' he has some little Faults, Time and your Virtues will cor∣rect them.—Come, what shall I write?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Pray give me a Moment's Thought;—'Tis a terrible Task, Mr. Heartly.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I know it is.—Don't hurry yourself:—I shall wait with Patience.—Come, Miss Harriet.

P.HI: It is in vain for me to conceal, from one of your Understanding, the Secrets of my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: The Secrets of my Heart—

P.HI: Tho' your Humility and Modesty will not suffer you to perceive it.—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Do you think, my Dear, that he is much troubled with those Qualities?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Pray indulge me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I beg your Pardon.—Your Humility and Modesty will not suffer you to perceive it.—(Writes) So.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Every thing tells you, that it is you that I love.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Very well. (Writes.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Yes:—You that I love;—do you understand me?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: O! yes, yes;—I understand you,—that it is You that I love.—This is very plain, my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I would have it so.—And tho' I am already bound in Gratitude to you.—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: In Gratitude to Mr. Clackit?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Pray write, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Well,—In Gratitude to you; (writes.)—I must write what she would have me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Yet my Passion is a most disinterested one.—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Most disinterested one.

P.HI: And to convince you, that you owe much more to my Affections,—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: And then?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I could wish that I had not experienced—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Stay,—Stay:—had not experienced—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Your tender Care of me in my Infancy.—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY
SP.P: What did you say?—Did I hear right, or am I in a Dream!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Why have I declared myself?—He'll hate me my Folly.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Harriet!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: To whom do you write this Letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: To—to—Mr. Clackit,—is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: You must not mention then the Care of your In∣fancy; it would be ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: It would indeed;—I own it;—It is improper.—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: What, did it escape you in your Confusion?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: It did indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: What must I put in its Place?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Indeed I don't know.—I have said more than enough to make myself understood.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Then I'll only finish your Letter with the usual Compliment, and send it away.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Yes,—Send it away,—If you think I ought to send it.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Ought to send it!—Who's there?—(Enter a Servant) Carry this Letter.

DIV3.STAGE: (An Action escapes from Harriet, as if to hinder the sending the Letter.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET. Peevishly.
SP.P: Who can it be for?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY. (To the Servant.)
SP.P: Here take this Letter to Mr. Clackit.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: What a terrible Situation!

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I am thunderstruck!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I cannot speak another Word.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: My Prudence fails me!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: He disapproves my Passion, and I shall die with Confussion.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: The Conversation is over, and I may appear. (Aside.)—Sir Charles is without, Sir, and is im∣patient to know your Determination;—May he be permitted to see you?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY. (Aside.)
SP.P: I must retire to conceal my Weakness.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Upon my Word this is very whimsical.—What is the Reason, Miss, that your Guardian is gone away without giving me an Answer?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET. (Aside.)
SP.P: What a Contempt he must have for me, to be∣have in this Manner!

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Extremely well, this, and equally Foolish on both Sides!—But what can be the Meaning of it?—Ho, ho,—I think I have a Glimmer∣ing at last.—Suppose she shou'd not like young Shatter-brains after all; and indeed she has never absolutely said she did; who knows but she has at last opened her Mind to my good Master, and he, finding her Taste (like that of other Girls at her Age) most particularly ridiculous, has not been so Complaisant as he used to be.—What a Shame it is that I don't know more of this Mat∣ter, a Wench of Spirit, as I am, a Favourite of my Mistress, and as inquisitive as I ought to be? It is an Affront to my Character, and I must have Satisfaction immediately.—(Going.) I will go directly to my young Mistress, teize her to death, till I am at the Bottom of this; and if Threat∣ning, Soothing, Scolding, Whispering, Crying, and Lying will not prevail, I will e'en give her Warning,—And go upon the Stage.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P:
The more I reflect upon what has pass'd, the more I am convinc'd that she did not intend wri∣ting to this young Fellow.—What am I think of it then?—Let a Man be ever so much upon his Guard against the Approaches of Vanity, yet he will find himself weak in that Quarter.— Had not my Reason made a little Stand against my Presumption, I might have interpreted some of Harriet's Words in my own Favour; but—
I may well blush, tho' alone, at my extravagant Folly!—Can it be possible that so young a Crea∣ture shou'd even cast a Thought of that kind upon me?—Upon me! Presumptuous Vanity!— No, no,—I will do her and myself the Justice to acknowledge that, for a very few slight Ap∣pearances, there are a thousand Reasons that de∣stroy so ridiculous a Supposition.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Heartly, what are we to hope for?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Upon my Word, Sir, I am still in the Dark; we puzzle about, indeed, but we don't get for∣ward.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: What the Devil is the Meaning of all this? There never sure were Lovers so difficult to bring together. But have you not been a little too rough with the Lady? For as I pass'd by her but now, she seem'd a little out of Humour,—And, up∣on my Faith, not the less beautiful for a little pouting.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Upon my Word, Sir Charles, what I can collect from her Behaviour is, that your Nephew is not so much in her good Graces, as he made you be∣lieve.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P:
'Egad, like enough;—But hold, hold,— this must be look'd a little into;—if it is so, I wou'd be glad to know, why, and wherefore, I have been made so ridiculous.—Eh, Ma∣ster
Heartly, does he take me for his Fool, his Beast, his Merry Andrew? By the Lord Harry—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: In him a little Vanity is excusable.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I am his Vanity's humble Servant for that tho'.—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: He is of an Age, Sir Charles—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, of an Age to be very impertinent; but I shall desire him to be less free with his Uncle for the future, I assure him.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: I have it, I have it, Gentlemen! You need not puzzle any more about the Matter.—I have got the Secret.—I know the Knight-Errant that has wounded our distress'd Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Well, and who? And what, Child?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: What, has not she told you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Not directly.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: So much the better.—What Pleasure it is to discover a Secret, and then tell it to all the World!—I press'd her so much, that she at last con∣fess'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Well, what?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: That, in the first place, she did not like your Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: And I told the Puppy so.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: That she had a most mortal Antipathy for the young Men of this Age; and that she had settled her Affections upon one of riper Years, and riper Understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: And that she expected from a Lover in his Au∣tumn more Affection, more Complaisance, more Constancy, and more Discretion of Course.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: That is very particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, but it is very prudent for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: In short, as she had openly declared against the Nephew, I took upon me to speak of his Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Of me, Child?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Yes, of you, Sir;—And she did not say me Nay,—But cast such a Look, and fetch'd such a Sigh,—That if ever I look'd and sigh'd in my Life, I know how it is with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: What the Devil!—Why surely,—Eh, Lucy! You joke for certain,—Mr. Heartly!—Eh!—

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Indeed I do not, Sir,—'Twas in vain for me to say that nothing coud be so ridiculous as such a Choice.—Nay, Sir, I went a little further, (You'll excuse me) and told her—Good God Madam, said I, why he is Old and Gouty, Ast∣matic, Rheumatic, Sciatic, Spleen-atic.—It sig∣nified nothing, she had determined.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: But you need not have told her all that.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I am persuaded, Sir Charles, that a good Heart, and a good Mind will prevail more with that young Lady, than the more fashionable Accomplish∣ments.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, Neighbour, I have had my Days, and have been well receiv'd among the Ladies, I have—But in Truth, I am rather in my Winter than my Autumn; she must mean somebody else. Now I think again—It can't be me—No, no, it can't be me.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P:
But I tell you it is, Sir.—You are the Man,—
Her Stars have decreed it; and what they decree, tho' ever so ridiculous, must come to pass.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Say you so?—Why then, Monsieur Nephew, I shall have a little Laugh with you,—Ha, ha, ha! The Tit-bit is not for you, my nice Sir.—Your Betters must be serv'd before you.—But here he comes—Not a Word for your Life.—We'll laugh at him most triumphantly.—Ha, ha! but Mum, Mum.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: That will do most divinely well.—Bravo, Bravo! Messieurs Vocal and Instrumental!—Stay in that Chamber, and I will let you know the Time for your Appearance. (To the Musicians.) Meeting by Accident with some Artists of the String, and my particular Friends, I have brought 'em to celebrate Miss Harriet's and my approaching Happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Do you hear the Puppy?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: It is time to clear up all Mistakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Now for it.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Miss Harriet, Sir, was not destin'd for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: What do you say, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: That the young Lady has fix'd her Affections upon another.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Upon another?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, Another,—That is English, Sir, and you may translate it into French, if you like it better.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Vous êtes bien drole mon Oncle.—Ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, ay, shew your Teeth, you have nothing else for it;—But she has fix'd her Heart upon Another, I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Very well, Sir, extremely well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: And that other, Sir, is one to whom you owe great Respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: I am his most respectful humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: You are a fine Youth, my sweet Nephew, to tell me a Story of a Cock and a Bull, of you and the young Lady, when you have no more Interest in her than the Czar of Muscovy.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: But my dear Uncle, don't carry this Jest too far,—I shall begin to be uneasy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, ay, I know your Vanity: You think now that the Women are all for you young Fellows.—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Nine Hundred and Ninety-nine in a Thousand, I believe, Uncle, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: You'll make a damn'd foolish Figure, by and by, Jack.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Whoever my precious Rival is, he must prepare himself for a little Humility; for be he ever so mighty, my dear Uncle, I have that in my Pocket will lower his Top-sails for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Well, what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: A Fourteen Pounder only, my good Uncle,—A Letter from the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: What, to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: To me, Sir,—This Moment receiv'd, and overflowing with the tenderest Sentiments.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: To you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P:
Most undoubtedly.—She reproaches me with
my excessive Modesty.—There can be no Mi∣take.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: What, Letter is this he chatters about?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: One written by me, and dictated by the young Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: What sent by her to him?

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I believe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Well, but then,—How the Devil,—Mrs. Lucy!—Eh!—What becomes of your fine Story?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: I don't understand it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Nor I!

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: Nor—I—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: But I do,—And so you will all presently.— Well, my dear Uncle, what are you astonished, petrify'd, annihilated?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: With your Impudence, Jack!—But I'll see it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Bless me, Mr. Heartly, what is all this Music for in the next Room?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: I brought the Gentlemen of the String, Made∣moiselle, to convince you, that I feel, as I ought, the Honour you have done me—(Shewing the Letter.) But for Heaven's sake be sincere a little with these good Folks; they tell me here that I am Nobody, and there is another happier than myself, and for the Soul of me, I don't know how to be∣lieve 'em,—Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Let us hear Miss speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: It is a most terrible Task; but I am compel'd to it, and to hesitate any longer wou'd be injurious to my Guardian, his Friend, this young Gentleman, and my own Character.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Most judicious, upon my Soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Hold your Tongue, Jack.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: I am Dumb.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: You have all been in an Error.—My Bashfulness may have deceiv'd you,—My Heart never did.—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: C'est vrai.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Therefore, before I declare my Sentiments, it is proper that I disavow any Engagement:—but at the same time must confess—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Ho,—ho!—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: With Fear and Shame confess—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Courage, Mademoiselle!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: That Another, not You, Sir, has gain'd a Power over my Heart.—(To Y. Clackit.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Another, not you; mind that, Jack. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: It is a Power indeed which he despises.—I cannot be deceived in his Conduct.—Modesty may tye the Tongue of our Sex, but Silence in him could proceed only from Contempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: How prettily she reproaches me!—But I'll soon make it up with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P:
As to that Letter, Sir; your Error there, is ex∣cusable; and I own myself in that Particular a little blameable—But it was not my Fault that it was sent
to you; and the Contents must have told you, that it could not possibly be meant for you. (To Y. Clackit.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Proof positive, Jack:—Say no more.—Now is my Time to begin.—Hem!—hem!—Sweet young Lady,—hem!—whose Charms are so mighty, so far transcending every thing that we read of, in History or Fable, how could you possibly think that my Si∣lence proceeded from Contempt? Was it natural or prudent, think you, for a Man of sixty-five, nay, just entering into his sixty-sixth year—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: O Misericorde! What, is my Uncle my Rival! Nay then I shall burst, by Jupiter!—Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Don't imagine, Sir, that to me your Age is any Fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: You are very obliging, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: Neither is it, Sir, a Merit of that extraordinary Na∣ture, that I should sacrifice to it an Inclination which I have conceived for another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: How is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Another! not you.—mind that, Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: What is the Meaning of all this!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Proof positive, Uncle—And very positive.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I have been led into a Mistake, Madam, which I hope you will excuse; and I have made myself very ridiculous, which I hope I shall forget:—And so, Madam, I am your humble Servant.—This young Lady has something very extraordinary about her.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: What I now see and the Remembrance of what is past force me to break Silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: Ay, now for it.—Hear him—hear him.—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: O my Harriet!—I too must be disgrac'd in my Turn.—Can you think that I have seen and convers'd with you unmov'd?—Indeed I have not.—The more I was sensible of your Merit, the stronger were my Motives to stifle the Ambition of my Heart.— But now I can no longer resist the Violence of my Passion, which casts me at your Feet, the most un∣worthy indeed of all your Admirers, but of all the most affectionate.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: So, so, the Moon has changed, and the grown Gentlemen begin to be frisky.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: What, my Master in Love too!—I'll never trust these Tye Wigs again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARRIET.
SP.P: I have refused my Hand to Sir Charles and this young Gentleman:—The one accuses me of Caprice, the other of Singularity.—Should I refuse my Hand a third Time, (smiling) I might draw upon myself a more servere Reproach,—and therefore I accept your Favour, Sir, and will endeavour to deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: And thus I feal my Acknowledgments, and from henceforth devote my every Thought, and all my Services to the Author of my Happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Since Matters are so well settled, give me leave, Sir, to congratulate you on your Success,—and my young Lady on her Judgment.—You have my Taste exactly, Miss; ripe Fruit for my Money; when it is too green it sets one's Teeth on edge, and when too mellow it has no Flavour at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Hold your Tongue, you Baggage, (to Lucy.)— Well, my dear discreet Nephew, are you satisfied with the Fool's Part you have given me, and play'd your∣self, in the Farce?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. CLACKIT.
SP.P: What would you have me say, Sir? I am too much a Philosopher to fret myself, because the Wind, which was East this Morning, is now West.—The poor Girl in pique has kill'd herself, to be reveng'd on me; but hark'ye, Sir, I believe Heartly will be cursed mad to have me live in his Neighbourhood.— A Word to the Wise.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Thou hast a most incorrigible Vanity, Jack, and nothing can cure thee.—Mr. Heartly, I have Sense enough, and Friendship enough, not to be uneasy at your Happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTLY.
SP.P: I hope, Sir Charles, that we shall still continue to live as Neighbours and Friends. For you, my Har∣riet, Words cannot express my Wonder or my Joy; my future Conduct must tell you what a Sense I have of my Happiness, and how much I shall endeavour to deserve it.

DIV3.L: My friendly Care shall change to grateful Love,
And the fond Husband still the GUARDIAN prove.
